Award.AwardTitle: Generative Modeling with Short Run Computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
In our daily lives, we constantly receive a large amount of sensory data in the form of images, texts, and speech, yet we can effortlessly make sense of the data by learning, recognizing, and understanding the patterns and meanings in the data. How this is done by the brain is still largely a mystery, and this is a central problem in machine learning and artificial intelligence, which has a vast scope of applications and is transforming our lives. One way to make sense of sensory data is to construct models to generate them, by assuming that the data are generated by some relatively simple hidden factors or causes. Such models are called generative models. To make sense of the data is to infer the hidden causes that generate the input data, and this can be accomplished by short-run computing dynamics. The main goal of this project is to develop such generative models and the associated short-run computing dynamics. The project has the potential to lead to new learning techniques that can be useful in applications such as computer vision. The PI will also train graduate students supported by this grant and further enhance the graduate and undergraduate courses taught by the PI.

Generative models unify supervised, unsupervised, and semi-supervised learning in a principled likelihood-based framework. While supervised learning has met tremendous successes in recent years, unsupervised and semi-supervised learning remains a challenge. The bottleneck for likelihood-based learning of generative models is the intractable computation of expectations which usually requires expensive Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling, whose convergence can be problematic. The main motivation of the research is to get around this bottleneck. The following are specific aims of the proposed research: (1) Variational optimization of short-run MCMC dynamics for the sampling computations in likelihood-based learning of generative models, by combining the advantages of MCMC and variational inference. (2) Developing biologically plausible generative models with multiple layers of hidden variables, and the associated short-run inference and synthesis dynamics that can account for feedbacks and inhibitions between hidden variables.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced artificial intelligence by developing new statistical methods that enable AI systems to learn and reason more efficiently. The research focused on creating "generative models" - AI systems that can learn patterns from data and then generate new examples or solve complex problems. A key innovation was developing "short run computing" methods that allow these systems to learn and make decisions quickly using limited computational steps, similar to how biological brains process information through brief bursts of neural activity.

The project achieved several significant breakthroughs. In drug discovery, we developed new AI methods that can design molecules with desired properties, demonstrating superior performance in creating potential drug candidates for targets like PHGDH in cancer treatment. Our system successfully reproduced expert-designed compounds while also discovering novel variants with improved properties. In AI planning, we created new methods that can help AI systems learn complex behaviors from demonstrations, while using significantly fewer computational resources than traditional approaches.

Beyond technical achievements, the project made substantial educational impacts. We trained Ph.D. students with strong representation from underrepresented groups including Hispanic students and female researchers. Our Ph.D. graduates have secured positions at leading institutions - two as tenure-track faculty members, while others joined premier AI research teams at leading technology companie. The project helped the education of over 30 Master's students since 2019, and more than 70 Applied Master's students since 2018. We also engaged undergraduate students in research and conducted K-12 outreach activities.

The research has promising applications in healthcare through drug discovery, in robotics through improved learning algorithms, and in computer vision through advanced image and video generation techniques. The project resulted in 46 papers published in top conferences and journals. The educational materials developed, including a comprehensive 400+ page machine learning textbook, will benefit future generations of students in this rapidly evolving field.

This work has helped bridge the gap between statistical theory and modern artificial intelligence, contributing to more efficient and interpretable AI systems while training a diverse workforce for future innovation in this critical field.
